peti7788,"2021-12-16T06:37:57.423Z","Blue track era with minifigures, strange","

I find these train themed sets, released in 1978, interesting and special.
column2: For several reasons. First, its box is different from other town sets.&nbsp
column3: Very nice green paint. And those backgrounds reminiscent of an old storybook. I love it!&nbsp

column1: In 1978, no minifigure with a printed torso was issued.
column3: But one of the guys here already has a printed torso. Would this be the first printed torso minifigure?&nbsp
column4: Another curiosity is the yellow safety helmet. Very rare, it was only in this single set for a long time. Unless only one exists in this set.

column1: Or anyone who was a kid at this time used to get the minifigures issued with the gray 12-volt rail tracks.
column3: s pretty weird to see the old 4.5-volt blue track in this set. Not a very common sight.&nbsp
column5: s like a glitch in the matrix.

column1: The flat wagon is the same as the other blue-track railroad cars of the 1970s.
The yellow car is quite a disappointment. On the one hand, you can'
column2: t put a minifigure in it, which spoils the gameplay.&nbsp
column3: On the other hand, it was in 1978 that the car chassis part and the steering wheel appeared.&nbsp
column4: But even without a chassis, a simple convertible could have been built from a couple of bricks and plates.&nbsp
column5: If you have the box, there is a version on the back of the box between the alternative builds where you can put the minifigure on the vehicle.

column1: I quickly built another car that also consists of a few parts. The point is to be able to put the minifigure in it.
